title: Doctor Sleep bosses lift lid on potential Jack Nicholson cameo
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

The director and producer behind Doctor Sleep has opened up on the behind-the-scenes efforts of potentially getting Jack Nicholson back for the follow up to The Shining.

Legendary Nicholson played Jack Torrance in the 1980 film, directed by Stanely Kubrick, based on Stephen King’s novel and now Doctor Sleep, also penned by King, catches up with Jack’s son, Danny (Ewan McGregor), an adult living with the ‘shining’.

Without giving too much away, of course it was something Mike Flanagan, who directed and wrote the screenplay, and producer Trevor Macy (the forces also behind The Haunting Of Hill House) thought about when putting this masterpiece together.

In the trailer alone we see the hint of the famous axe scene, as Ewan peers through the iconic hole in the door following Jack’s haunting ‘Here’s Johnny!’ moment from the original film.

With the lingering memory of that scene, was there thought to get Jack involved? Somehow?

Iconic (Picture: Rex Features)

Doctor Sleep riffs on the famous door (Picture: Warner Bros)

‘There were definitely discussions about it, the question was always in what way and what would be appropriate given the mythology of the hotel and how Kubrick has taught us what happens to ghosts and people who are killed in the hotel,’ Flanagan told Metro.co.uk ahead of Doctor Sleep’s release this week.

‘What we knew that we never wanted to do with any of the characters was try to artificially recreate other actors. We never wanted there to be a digital Wendy Torrance or Scatman Crothers [who played Dick Hallorann].

‘It was very important to us we cast actors like Carl Lumbly and Alex Essoe who would remind of us of Dick and Wendy but would still be playing the characters and doing it their way.’

Trevor Macy and Mike Flanagan are behind Doctor Sleep (Picture: Getty Images)

He added: ‘When it came to Jack Nicholson, he is very serious about being retired and they had tried to get him to come out and do a cameo in Ready Player One. And he had said no Steven Spielberg.

‘The thought he’d be like “well, Mike Flanagan…” [laughs] I didn’t think that was going to be realistic.’

Flanagan continued: ‘He knew what we were doing from the beginning and wished us well.’

In the film, Doctor Sleep tackles iconic scenes from the Shining, which were recreated for our viewing pleasure. Yes, including the famed blood-pouring walls.

The director admitted it was ‘the most intimidating’ challenge to undertake, but he was adamant in not trying to ‘out Kubrick Kubrick’.

‘As long as we were coming from a place of reverence and trying to celebrate Kubrick’s film and King’s books that if we approached it from that perspective then that was the only way forward,’ Mike said.

Macy chimed in: ‘King gave us a fabulous blueprint because Doctor Sleep is very much its own story…there is a lot of rich dramatic ground to cover when you’re talking about little Danny Torrance all grown up, his childhood is burned into everyone’s brains and what would it be like to grow up with that is a really good question.’

Doctor Sleep is in UK cinemas Thursday.
